Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports U.S. participation in a U.S.-Japan workshop on rescue robots to be held at Texas A&M University?s Disaster City on March 8-11, 2010. The workshop will be organized in conjunction with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Response Robot Evaluation Exercise #6 and builds on an August 2008 U.S.-Japan workshop on robotics for safety, security and better quality of life. The award supports travel for six U.S. research teams, with one senior researcher and two student assistants per team, to the workshop. Professor Satoshi Tadokoro of Tohoku University Department of Information Sciences is the lead Japanese collaborator.

The TAMU meeting offers U.S. researchers in rescue robots (platforms, sensors, human-robot interactions) an uncommon opportunity to improve their understanding of real-world domains by testing their robots and sensors with NIST standards at the unique facility at Disaster City and obtaining feedback from responders. The workshop is expected to contribute to the theory of rescue robots and establish new collaborations. It fosters U.S.-Japan collaborations through fieldwork, presentations and information interactions. Recent earthquakes in Haiti and Chile make the workshop especially timely. The Directorate for Computer and Information Science & Engineering Division of Information and Intelligent Systems cofunded this award.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On March 8-11, 2010, the Center for Robot-Assisted Search and Rescue (CRASAR) at Texas A&M University hosted a workshop on rescue robotics. The workshop was sponsored by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the Japan Science and Technology Agency (JST), and the National Institute for Standards and Technology (NIST) and endorsed by the IEEE technical committee on Safety, Security, and Rescue Robots. A total of 50 researchers and 12 land, sea, and aerial robots participated, with 35 attendees from nine Japanese institutions under the International Rescue Systems Institute (Chiba Insti- tute of Technology, Kinki University, Kobe City College of Technology, Kyoto University, Nagaoka University of Technology, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, National Research Institute for Earth Science and Disaster Prevention, Tohoku University, and Tokyo Institute of Technology), fourteen attendees from six American universi- ties (Denver University, Ohio State, Texas A&M, University of Pennsylvania, Vanderbilt, Virginia Tech), and one attendee from China (Shenyang Institute of Automation). The first two days of the three and a half day workshop took advantage of the NIST Response Robot Evaluation Exercise #6 held at Texas A&M’s Disaster City to provide hands-on experimentation and interaction with responders. The fourth day was held on campus and consisted of follow up presentations and discussions on recommendations for standards and on lessons learned.

The intellectual merit of the workshop was captured by four objectives, each of which were met: 1) Enable researchers in the US to improve their under- standing of real-world domains by testing their robots and sensors with NIST Standards at the unique facility at Disaster City and obtain feedback from responders, 2) Encourage US researchers with robots that are not covered by current NIST standards to participate and propose new standards and metrics, 3) Foster collaboration from the previous 2008 NSF-JST workshop through fieldwork, presentations, and informal interactions, and 4) Provide a venue for presentations and proceedings reflecting the state of the art in US-Japan initiatives in rescue robotics. The workshop and field exercise provided hands-on experience for the next generation of researchers, identification of new standards and test methods, produced a report to the ASTM standards committee, produced two papers to date, including for PerMIS which is the premiere robotics standards venue, and increased the number of US-Japan collaborations and international grants (NSF-RAPID, JST-RAPID).

This project had a broad societal impact through the use of robots for response and recovery at the Great East Japan (Sendai) Earthquake and Tsunami. The relationships and trust in the equipment from the exercise and workshop laid the foundation for the use of response robots by participants (Kimura, Matsuno, Murphy, and Ta- dokoro) to create a joint Japan-US team to use unmanned marine vehicles at the Great East Japan Earthquake (April 17-24, 2011) with funding from NSF and JST. Without this workshop, the Japanese would not have seen the suitability of UMVs for response and recovery and thus would not have requested that technology. The UMVs were able to open a fishing village’s port and ruled out the presence of victims in flotsam that was unable to be searched by the Japanese Coast Guard.
